history.content: I would personally say that if you want to do "ML-related work", you really should prioritize taking 189 over 126/127.

children.subject: I disagree with this. I found 126 much more useful/necessary for 189 or ML than 127 and I feel like a lot of the material of 127 can be self-studied once you have taken 16B. If you really care about the math behind ML, you need to have a solid grasp of probability.

Having taken all three courses, if you have a solid understanding of 126 and 127 I would say you absolutely have the mathematical background required to self-study all of the 189 material. However, 126 and 127 are fairly challenging courses (especially 126). If your primary reason for taking 126 is solely as a proxy or prereq for 189 I would not recommend taking it at all. If you really want to focus on ML, I would recommend just 189 or a 189/127 combo.

history.content:
Right now I'm planning on taking 162, 123, and 189 next semester. But I'm considering swapping 189 for 186 in the case that this schedule is too much for me. I've survived high workloads in the past, but I'm not sure about this one. 

I will be taking 127 and 126 fall 2020 (my last semester before I graduate). Is it difficult to learn the material taught in 189 on my own if I have taken 126 and 127? I'm really interested in ML and in an ideal world I would have taken all these classes. I would love to do ML related work and having coursework to back me up would be nice, but is self learning ML in the depth and breadth taught in 189 doable?
history.subject: Learning 189 on my own after taking 126 and 127?
